title: Stiperstones Walk Route

images.title: Derek Harper / One of the Stiperstones
images.caption: One of the Stiperstones. A smaller but distinctively shaped rock, this is located between Manstone Rock and Cranberry Rock (in the distance).

images.title: Derek Harper / The Stiperstones
images.caption: Left of centre is The Devil's Chair, which may resemble a chair from some directions. It is the largest and best known of the rocks on the ridge. The Shropshire Way passes between it and the nearer rock on the right.

images.title: David Gruar / Meadow on the Stiperstones ridge
images.caption: Meadow on the Stiperstones ridge. This field full of wild flowers is on the col between Nipstone Rock and Cranberry Rock. I think the building on the right is recently constructed.

images.title: George Mahoney / Near the Stiperstones
images.caption: Looking Northeast from the car park below the Stiperstones towards the Hollies and the hills beyond

images.title: Richard Law / Shepherd's Rock from the Stiperstones bridleway
images.caption: Shepherd's Rock from the Stiperstones bridleway. The rock is the last of the substantial tors on the main ridge. There is another outcrop a little further NE, looking out to the east, but it's off the main track, and thus rarely visited.

images.title: Derek Harper / Shropshire Way
images.caption: Photo taken from the point at which the Shropshire Way, having climbed from Bridges, reaches the ridge, here heading southwest from a crossroads of path and bridleways towards the main line of rocks. The path starts to get rough as irregular quartzite rocks form an increasing part of it. A teasing burst of sun southwards on a bitterly cold and cloudy day in December.

images.title: Stiperstone from Stiperstones. by Simon Huguet, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
Stiperstones (1) by Stephen Richards, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

description: The area around this popular Shropshire Hill is fantastic for walking and cycling. This walk takes you to the 536 m (1,759 ft) Stiperstones summit where you can enjoy fabulous views over the surrounding area. The Stiperstones is a 6 mile/10km ridge covered with craggy rock outcrops and gorgeous heather heathland. The area is also a National Nature Reserve with a diverse range of flora and fauna. Look out for red grouse, Eurasian curlew, peregrine falcon and the rare ring ouzel as you make your way across the hills. This walk begins in Habberley taking you through woodland to the Stiperstones ridge. You head along the ridge passing the quartzite tors that Stiperstones is famous for. These include Shepherd's Rock, the Devil's Chair and Manstone Rock. Manstone is the highest at 536 metres (1,759 ft) and commands fabulous views over the Shropshire Hills, the Long Mynd and Wales. From here you return to Habberley on  different tracks, passing through a series of wooded areas as you go. If you'd like to continue your climbing in the area then you could head to the nearby Caer Caradoc and the stunning Long Mynd. This route also makes use of the Shropshire Way so you could continue along this path to the Bog Mine Visitor Centre where you'll find historical information about the area and two circular walks.
